newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Macquarie Bank sees higher zinc prices.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Macquarie Bank sees higher zinc prices.

text.p: Zinc prices should average 56 US cents a pound or higher this year and 65 cents in 1998, Macquarie Bank Ltd analyst Jim Lennon said on Friday.

The forecasts were based on expectation of growth in consumption of zinc of around two to three percent a year and the influence of hedge funds in the marketplace, Lennon told a Macquarie Bank symposium on the zinc industry.
Zinc in 1996 averaged 46 cents a pound. It ended Lonon Metal Exchange afternoon trading Thursday at 58 cents a pound, near a four-and-a-half-year high.
"We've liked zinc for a year now," Lennon said.
Lennon said zinc stocks were finally declining as a period of industry destocking winds down, placing upward pressure on the price.
The key stocks-to-consumption ratio of zinc was currently around 6.5 weeks and heading down toward a "critical level" by mid-year, Lennon said.
"We haven't quite reached that critical level yet," he said.
However, by the end of the year, the ratio would have slipped to an average of 5.2 weeks, Lennon said.
In 1998, the average would fall further to 3.8 weeks, he said.
On the supply side, he said there was little to suggest so far that the Anvil Range Mining Corp was in a hurry to restart it Faro zinc mine in Canada.
The mine was idled on December 20 due to poor market conditions, a strong Canadian dollar and delays in stripping the mine.
But even with the resurgence in zinc prices, Faro's restart could be a way's off, Lennon said.
"We've had no impression of a restart," Lennon said.
Failure of the lead prices to parallel zinc, could be discouraging Anvil from re-opening the mine, Lennon said.
In the 14 months ended December 31, Faro produced 345,700 tonnes of zinc concentrates and 186,000 tonnes of lead concentrates, making it one of the world's biggest mines for both metals.

Another factor weighing on Anvil was the planned start-up of the Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd Cannington lead and zinc mine in Australia, which was scheduled to begin producing 250,000 tonnes of lead and 100,000 tonnes of zinc concentrates a year next year, Lennon suggested.
Growth in zinc consumption should average 2.7 percent this year, rising to 3.1 percent in 1998, Lennon said.
A lift in prices also would be aided by less Chinese metal exported to other markets, as China now faces limited concentrate production capacity and domestic consumption builds, Lennon said.
While there are probably around 250 zinc smelters in China, about 200 of the smelters only produce between 5,000 and 10,000 tonnes of zinc a year, he added.
-- James Regan, Sydney Newsroom 61-2 9373-1800
